Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the father should provide guidance
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and notifications pinging relentlessly. My son, Ethan, was across from me, fidgeting with his spoon, milk dripping onto the table. “Ethan, remember to use your napkin,” I reminded him, trying to keep my voice gentle. He looked up, eyes searching mine for approval or disappointment. At the same moment, a Slack message popped up: “Need your input on the API design—can you review now?” My team was waiting, the deadline for the design documents looming. I could almost feel their impatience through the screen.

Ethan slurped his cereal, and I caught myself sighing. I wanted to be present, to teach him patience and respect at the table, to model the values I hoped he’d carry into adulthood. But the pressure from work was mounting, and I knew my absence would slow the project, frustrate my colleagues, maybe even jeopardize the release. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to guide my son and the demand to support my team. I stared at Ethan, then at my laptop, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which to choose.
